Carpal Tunnel Syndrome_1:
Case 1:
   A 45-year-old female patient, who reports a history of working in data entry for the past 10 years, presented with a tingling sensation and occasional sharp pain (rated 4/10 on the pain scale) in her right hand and forearm. She has noticed a reduction in the muscle mass at the base of her right thumb. The patient's BMI is within the overweight range. These symptoms have been progressively worsening over the last six months and are aggravated during repetitive hand and wrist movements at work. Clinical evaluation revealed a positive Tinel's sign and Phalen's test. The patient has not undergone any prior treatment for these symptoms.
Carpal Tunnel Syndrome_2:
Case 2:
   A 35-year-old male, working in a manufacturing plant with a high hand and wrist repetitive task rate, presented with a six-month history of numbness and pain in his right hand and fingers, which he rates as 6/10 in intensity. The patient has noticed a visible loss of muscle mass in the thenar eminence of the affected hand. His BMI is within the normal range. The symptoms are exacerbated during work hours and improve with rest. Physical examination revealed a positive Tinel's sign and Phalen's test. The patient has not received any prior treatment for these symptoms.
Carpal Tunnel Syndrome_3:
Case 3:
   A 50-year-old male with a history of working as a professional pianist for 20 years presented with a chief complaint of persistent numbness and occasional pain (rated 5/10) in his right hand and wrist. The patient has observed a noticeable shrinkage in the muscle bulk of his right thenar eminence. His BMI is within the normal range. Symptoms have been ongoing for nine months and are exacerbated during prolonged piano playing sessions. Clinical assessment demonstrated a positive Tinel's sign and Phalen's test. The patient has not undergone any prior treatment for these symptoms.
